source: Hi, everybody.
target: Hi, everybody.

source: This is actor advocate Andy Arias.
target: This is Andy Arias, I am an actor and advocate.

source: Happy ADA 30.
target: So happy to celebrate with you 30 years since the Americans with Disabilities Act (the ADA) became a law.

source: I want to take a quick second to give a shout out to disabilityunite.org.
target: I want to say thank you to disabilityunite.org.

source: Thank you for putting on such an amazing event.
target: Thank you for this amazing event.

source: Thank you to Corey and Elizabeth for inviting me to do this.
target: Thank you to Corey and Elizabeth for inviting me to talk to you.

source: You guys, it is almost November. What does that mean? It is time to go out and vote.
target: You know, it is almost November. That means it is almost time to go vote.

source: Now, more than ever, your choices and your voices matter.
target: Now, more than ever, your choices (and your votes) can make a difference.

source: So whether you are on the right or the left side, your voice needs to be heard in November.
target: No matter whom you want to vote for, it is important that you vote in November.

source: Know where your polling place are.
target: You should know where you could go to vote.

source: Know that there are absentee ballot options available, and there may be other options available depending on what situation we find ourselves in.
target: You should know if you could vote from home. You should check if there are other ways of voting this year because of covid-19.

source: We are the largest population, and any minority or majority on the planet-- it is time that we are equal in our voices and in our choices.
target: We are more than any other group in the whole world. We should be equal and have choices like everybody else.

source: Please do not forget to go out and vote in November.
target: To make sure we have choices please do not forget to go out and vote in November.

source: If I didn't speak up, would you notice me?
target: If I didn't speak out loud, would you pay attention to me?

source: 4 Wheel City presents The Movement.
target: The 4 Wheel City group presents The Movement.

source: This is a refreshers course.
target: In the next work, the artists want to remind us of something important.

source: We all travel in separate vehicles, right?
target: They remind us that we all move in different ways.

source: Cars, trucks, bicycles, wheelchairs, motorized wheelchairs, canes, crutches.
target: We walk and drive cars and bicycles but we also use wheelchairs and crutches.

source: Be aware, and kindly make an adjustment so that we can all get to where we're going.
target: So, we need to make sure we all pay attention to each other, we need to make sure everything is accessible so we can all get to where we want to go.

source: As I said in the beginning, this is a very unique time and space.
target: Like I said in the begining, we leave in a very special time.

source: So 4 Wheel City takes a moment to say thank you.
target: So 4 Wheel City group wants to to say thank you to the people who help us in covid-19 times.

source: 4 Wheel City.
target: 4 Wheel City.

source: Thank you so much for taking the time out to spend the evening with us.
target: Thank you so much for being with us tonight.

source: My name is Gha'il Rhodes Benjamin, as I told you before.
target: My name is Gha'il Rhodes Benjamin, as I told you before.

source: And I am an ally of disabled people.
target: I am a friend and supporter of disabled people.

source: We all breathe the same air.
target: We all breathe the same air.

source: We all share the same space.
target: We all share the same space.

source: And as Maya Angelou said, we have more in common than we realize.
target: And as Maya Angelou said, we have more thing that are the same then things that are different..

source: Have a wonderful summer.
target: Have a wonderful summer.

source: Stay safe.
target: Stay safe.

source: We love you.
target: We love you.

source: Thank you again for joining us.
target: Thank you again for being with us.

source: See you next time.
target: See you next time.

source: Good evening, everybody, and welcome to the Disability Unite Festival.
target: Good evening, everybody. Welcome to the Disability Unite Festival.

source: My name is Gha'il Rhodes Benjamin.
target: My name is Gha'il Rhodes Benjamin.

source: I'm so happy to be here with you this evening.
target: I am so happy to be here with you this evening.

source: This is a moment that we've all been anticipating.
target: This is a moment that everybody was waiting for.

source: It's a moment that's powerfully titled, "It Just Had to be Said".
target: It is a moment that we can call, "It just had to be said".

source: And all of the artists, including myself, in this next segment pretty much just let you know what needs to be said in protest of 2020, the us, the we, the they, the fear, the outrage, the defiance, all of us, you and I, redefining our identities.
target: The artists in the next part of the festival, including me, just say what we think. We just say what is wrong now, in 2020, what we need to change. How people just want to be with people they think are just like them and do not want to be with other people. We talk about being afraid, being angry, trying to say no, trying to know who we are.

source: These next few artist bring it to you and tell you just like it is.
target: The next artists tell you exactly what they think about all these things.

source: I finally get a chance to tell you a little bit about myself.
target: Now I can to tell you a little bit about myself.

source: Again, my name is Gha'il Rhodes Benjamin, performance spoken-word artist.
target: My name is Gha'il Rhodes Benjamin, I am an artist who performs with words.

source: This piece, written and performed by me, is titled Global Libations.
target: The piece that I will perform for you now is a piece that I wrote. I call this work Global Libations.

source: It's a memorial for the gone but not forgotten, the heroes and the sheroes that are no longer with us, gone from our dinner tables, from our neighborhoods, from our lives, leaving behind husbands, wives children, grandparents, elders, gone.
target: I wrote this in memory of the people who died and are no longer with us but we do not forget them. It is in memory of brave men and women who passed away. Who are not with us anymore. They are gone. They are not with us at dinner, and they are not with us in the neighborhood. They are not in our lives anymore. They had husbands and wifes, they had children and grandparents, and now they are gone.

source: Global Libations.
target: Global Libations.

source: Zazel O'Garra, founder and artistic director of ZCO Dance Project, is a force to be reckoned with.
target: Zazel O'Garra is the founder and artistic director of ZCO Dance Project. She is a very strong and important woman.

source: She's a powerful force in the artistic industry.
target: She is a powerful artist.

source: Nothing can slow her down. Nothing can pull her back.
target: Nothing can slow her down.

source: Nothing can hold Zazel down.
target: Nothing can slow her down. Nothing can stop her.

source: She is dynamite.
target: She has so much energy.

source: Her dancers defy gravity.
target: Her dancers jump so high (in the air).

source: They move through space and time effortlessly.
target: When they move it looks so easy.

source: It's as if they can never stop.
target: It looks like they can never stop.

source: Their sheer determination defies all odds.
target: They just keep on moving even when it looks impossible.

source: In this new piece, titled "We the People", choreographed by Wendy Powell, you'll get a chance to see what I'm talking about.
target: The name of their new dance is "We the People" the person who created the dance is Wendy Powell. Now you will see them.

source: Put your hands in the air.
target: Put your hands in the air.

source: Get ready.
target: Get ready.

source: ZCO Dance Project is coming to you right now.
target: ZCO Dance Project is starting right now.

source: Go, ZCO.
target: Go, ZCO.

source: Hi, Andrea.
target: Hi Andrea.

source: Welcome to Disability Night platform.
target: Welcome to Disability Night.

source: Thank you so much for coming today.
target: Thank you very much for coming.

source: We're very honored to have you.
target: We’re glad you are here.

source: You're known as the seated nurse.
target: You are called “the seated nurse”.

source: Could you give us a little bit of a back story about yourself and about your disability?
target: Can you tell us about yourself? And why they call you the seated nurse?

source: Yes, I'm the seated nurse.
target: Yes, I am called the seated nurse.

source: I'm the first registered nurse here in New York City to graduate out of nursing school and be a wheelchair user at the same time. And my little backstory is that I also have transverse myelitis.
target: I am the first person in New York City to become a nurse also use a wheelchair. I am using a wheelchair because I have a desease.

source: I was diagnosed at the age of five and completely stopped walking when I was 12 years old.
target: It started when I was five years old. I stopped walking when I was 12 years old.

source: - Wow.
target: Wow.

source: You're a very gifted, talented person.
target: You are a very talented person.

source: I've known you for a long time.
target: I have known you for a long time.

source: You've also been Miss Wheelchair New York.
target: You won the Ms. Wheelchair New York contest.

source: What made you want to become a nurse?
target: Why did you want to be a nurse?

source: - I actually didn't always want to be a nurse.
target: I did not always want to be a nurse.

source: I think a long time ago, we had spoken about representation and what that meant to us, right?
target: We talked about different jobs a long time ago.

source: And I didn't see people that look like nurses that look like me as a nurse-- not as a woman, not as a woman of color, but as a woman that had a disability.
target: I did not see any nurses with disabilities, who looked like me. There were women, and women of color, but not with disabilities, so I did not think about being a nurse.

source: I wanted to be a doctor.
target: I wanted to be a doctor.

source: I actually wanted to be a lawyer before that.
target: I also wanted to be a lawyer.

source: And in trying to get towards where I really wanted to be in life, I really thought about giving back and being of service to someone else.
target: I thought about what I really wanted to do. I wanted to help other people.

source: Medical school teaches you that you're treating a disease process, you're treating how a disease process works throughout someone's body.
target: In medical school, you learn how to treat a sickness in someone’s body.

source: I didn't want to treat someone like they were a disease process.
target: You treat the sickness and not the person.

source: I wanted to treat them as a person, so nursing fit right in there.
target: I wanted to help take care of the person and not the sickness. So I became a nurse.

source: So do you think then as a nurse that's in a chair, did you— do you think that there was any perks or beneficial aspects of being able to be relatable to people when you meet them in the patient setting?
target: Do you think that being in a wheelchair helps you in your job? Does it make it easier for your patients to talk to you?
Yes it does.

source: Being in the seated position or any disability at all, you are bringing a perspective that somebody might not have, right?
target: People see my disability and learn something new. They see things in a different way.

source: We know that disability is often deemed "the death sentence," quote unquote, right?
target: People sometimes think that if you have a disability, your life is over.

source: But when you come into nursing and you have your disability already and now you're at the bedside, that person knows that life goes on outside of the four walls of a hospital or outside the four walls of a clinic.
target: But when they see someone with a disability taking care of them, they understand that life goes on. They know they will not always be in the hospital.

source: You're giving them that new lease on life, a hope that probably doesn't come from a doctor or nurse that doesn't have a disability.
target: When they see me, it gives them hope that other doctors and nurses cannot give them.

source: It's definitely a different perspective.
target: It makes them understand things in a different way.

source: And we're innovators, so, of course, there's a perk there.
target: Also, we are doing something new.

source: We already know how to think 20 steps ahead.
target: We know how to plan ahead.

source: Exactly, exactly.
target: Exactly.

source: You recently were on the front lines of the COVID-19 crisis.
target: You helped take care of a lot of COVID-19 patients.

source: Could you tell us a little bit about that and your experiences?
target: Can you tell us about that?

source: - Yeah. COVID in New York, you guys all know, hit like a tornado came through.
target: You know that a lot of people in New York got COVID. It was very hard.

source: The amount of lives lost, the amount of those who are sick, the amount of those who are recovering is something that's going to be an endless journey from here on out.
target: A lot of people died. A lot of people got sick, and a lot of people are just starting to get better. It is going to take a very long time.

source: It's the new normal, they say, right?
target: People are saying that we have to get used to this.

source: This is not a normal that I want.
target: But I don’t want to get used to this.

source: We don't want to be on lock-down.
target: I don’t want to have to stay home.

source: We don't want to have our loved ones being sick or having to go through what COVID is doing to our bodies.
target: I don’t want so many people we love get sick and suffer from COVID.

source: So luckily, as those of us with disabilities already understand the scope of being excluded, possibly not leaving our homes, being afraid for going in and out of hospitals or clinics, we understand this life a little bit more, right?
target: Luckily, we - people with disabilities already understand the kind of life we all live now. People with disabilities understand what it is like not to be included. We know how sometimes it is hard to go out of our homes. We know about going to hospitals. We understand this life a little better than other people.

source: We can kind of adapt to it a little bit more than the general public.
target: It is easier for us to get used to living this way.

source: And we get to now step up and say, we know what this is like.
target: We have to tell people that we understand.

source: Share your stories.
target: We have to tell other people our stories.

source: Help everyone else get through it, because we still have to get through this together.
target: We have to help other people who do not know how to live this way.

source: Exactly, exactly.
target: Exactly.

source: What advice would you give to our community in general during this pandemic?
target: What do you want to tell people now, during COVID?

source: Because I know a lot of people have been isolated, which is maybe not normal from our normal routines or separate from our normal routines.
target: A lot of people are alone. This is not how they usually live. It is very different for them.

source: But what advice would you give to them to maintain a healthy lifestyle?
target: Can you give them ideas for how to stay healthy?

source: Try to avoid being out in big crowds right now.
target: Do not go to places were there are a lot of people.

source: If you do have to be out, wear a mask.
target: If you go outside, wear a mask.

source: Make sure you're washing your hands.
target: Wash your hands.

source: Don't miss appointments, OK, guys?
target: Go to the doctor when you have to.

source: I know a lot of us are staying away from clinics and hospitals, but you are only jeopardizing your health when you do that.
target: People do not like to go to the hospital or to the doctor now, but that is not safe.

source: Make sure that you are still getting out there to your physicians and making sure that you're getting the treatments that you need.
target: Keep going to the doctor to get what you need.

source: We want to make sure that we're keeping healthy.
target: We have to take care of ourselves and stay healthy.

source: And in order to do that, we need to follow up with our physicians.
target: We have to keep going to the doctor to stay healthy.

source: And I'm telling you as a nurse that has been in all of these buildings and has been at the bedside at the peak of COVID, they're putting in every precaution to make sure that we are staying healthy when we do enter into those settings.
target: I am a nurse and I go to hospitals and work with patients with COVID. I tell you that the hospitals are being very careful. The hospitals are careful so if we have to go to the hospital, we will not get COVID.

source: So please make sure that you're taking care of yourselves.
target: Take good care of yourself.

source: Get outside.
target: Go outside.

source: Call a friend.
target: Talk to your friends.

source: And don't think that you're alone through all of this. You're not.
target: Remember that you are not alone.

source: Yes, definitely.
target: Yes.

source: What advice would you give to somebody younger than you who wants to be a nurse or work in the health care industry?
target: What would you tell someone who is younger than you and wants to be a nurse or a doctor?

source: I imagine it wasn't an easy road for you to be understood and accepted into this-- into that community.
target: It was probably hard for you, for nurses and doctors to understand you and accept you.

source: It definitely was an uphill battle.
target: It was very hard work, that is true.

source: This is still a profession that needs to understand that disability does not equal inability, right?
target: Medical people still do not understand that being disabled does not mean you are unable to do things.

source: Just because I'm in a seated position does not mean that I cannot be of service to you in any which way or form.
target: I am sitting, but I can still help you with anything you need.

source: I think even within our own community, we try to put the same biases, this ablestic bias on ourselves like, oh, we can't do something because that's for someone who walks, or how would you be able to lift?
target: Sometimes, even we, people with disabilities, do not believe we can do things just because of our disability. We think we cannot do things because we cannot walk. We worry about how we will lift things.

source: All these questions about how can you do something?
target: We ask ourselves how we can do things.

source: The thing is we do things differently.
target: We just do things in a different way.

source: As someone with all different abilities, whether you have a hearing impairment, whether you have a vision impairment, whether you are standing or using crutches, whether you're using-- you can't lift or you must sit, we have different ways of being innovative in how we come up to a solution, right?
target: People have different abilities. Some people cannot hear well. Some people cannot see well. Some people can stand and some walk with crutches. Sometimes we cannot lift things. So we think of different ways of doing things.

source: Sometimes you need to ask for an extra hand, and sometimes you actually can do it by yourself.
target: Sometimes we ask for help, and sometimes we can do it ourselves.

source: So we have to remember that everyone's perception of us does not define us, right?
target: People look at us and think what we can or can't do, but that does not mean that is who we are.

source: So therefore, you get to choose how you wish to enter into this field and decide what your story's going to be.
target: We can choose how to become a doctor or a nurse. You can tell your own story.

source: No one else gets to decide that.
target: Nowbody gets to decide for you.

source: That's beautiful.
target: That’s beautiful.

source: Where do you see Andrea in 10 years from now?
target: What will you do in the future?

source: So right now, I am studying a master's in nursing education with the hopes of possibly become a doctorate of nursing practice within the next couple of years.
target: I am still studying. I am learning how to teach other people to become nurses. I hope to continue studying and become a better nurse.

source: I would love to be able to give back to our community.
target: I want to be able to do good things for our community.

source: It's really, really imperative that we have people in health care that understand our plight, they understand the disability world, they understand the disability from the side of having a disability and being able to then now treat it.
target: It is very important to have nurses and doctors that understand us and understand disabilities. People with disabilities understand what it is like, and now they can help treat disabilities too.

source: And not just treat and not understand, but to treat and understand.
target: They can treat people, and understand them.

source: That's beautiful.
target: What you said in beautiful.

source: Andrea Dalzell, thank you so much for being with us today here at Disability Unite.
target: Andrea Dalzell, thank you very much for talking at Disability Unite.

source: You are a visionary, in your words, you are an educator, and you are a inspiration to so many people.
target: You teach people, and give people hope.

source: You're a milestone in the community that is helping to push our community forward, so I personally thank you. I know the community I'm inspired by you every day.
target: You are making a big difference in our community and making our community better.

source: So thank you for being with us today, and we wish you the best of luck, and we'll definitely be following you.
target: Thank you very much, from the disabled community and from me. I learn a lot from you. Thank you for coming and good luck!

source: Thank you so much, Corey.
target: Thank you so much, Corey.

source: Thank you everyone.
target: Thank you everyone.

source: Take care.
target: Take care.

source: Bye.
target: Bye

source: Taking the stage next is Full Radius Dance.
target: Now we will see Full Radius Dance.

source: Based in Atlanta, Full Radius Dance is comprised of professional dancers with and without physical disabilities.
target: Full Radius Dance is a dance group from Atlanta. All the dancers are professional some have physical disabilities and some do not.

source: The company strongly illustrates the organization's belief that inclusion in the performing arts, and in particular dance, is capable of creating power, passion, and innovation.
target: The group believes that including different people in art and especially in dance makes people stronger. It makes people love each other.

source: Full Radius Dance maintains a busy performance schedule in Atlanta, as well as regionally, nationally, and internationally.
target: The group does a lot of shows. They perfom in Atlanta, in other states, and even in other countries.

source: The company will be performing Re-Emerge, the first in a three-part series with the overall title of Return.
target: The dance we will see is called Re-Emerge. The dance is part of a group of dances called Return.

source: Created for the camera with music by Andrew Choe, Re-Emerge is Full Radius Dance's response to the self-quarantining necessary due to COVID-19.
target: Andrew Choe wrote the music for the dance. The dance is about choosing to stay at home because of COVID.

source: How will we re-emerge?
target: It is also about what will happen when we can go back outside.

source: Re-Emerge is choreographed by the dancers under the artistic direction of Douglas Scott.
target: The dancers made the dance, and Douglas Scott was leading them.

source: You can find Full Radius Dance online at www.fullradiusdance.org. Twitter and Instagram are @FullRadiusDance.
target: You can learn more about Full Radius Dance on the internet at www.fullradiusdance.org, or at @FullRadiusDance on Twitter and Instagram.

source: Hi, I'm Jeff Tweedy from Wilco, and I'm here to introduce the next performer, Gaelynn Lea.
target: Hi, I'm Jeff Tweedy from the Wilco band. I am here to introduce Gaelynn Lea.

source: We met in-- I don't know, a few years back at a festival in Montana.
target: I met Gaelynn a few years ago at a festival in Montana.

source: And Gaelynn was one of those people that the instant you meet them, you feel like you've known them your whole life, and you're friends, or you're family, maybe, even.
target: Gaelynn is a special person because when you meet her you feel like you have known herfor a long time. You feel like you are friends, or even family.

source: She's opened up for Wilco.
target: Gaelynn started the show for the Wilco band performances.

source: She won a Tiny Desk Concert in 2016, and after that, she hit the road with her husband.
target: She won an award for her music. After she won, she did a music tour with her husband.

source: 45 states, nine countries later, she does a show every Sunday on YouTube.
target: She performed in many states, and even in other countries. Now she has a show every Sunday on YouTube.

source: And she just has infinite energy to make the world better.
target: She has a lot of energy and she just wants to make the world better.

source: I love her so much.
target: I love her so much.

source: And I can't wait for you to see her perform.
target: And I can't wait for you to see her perform.

source: Hello, everyone.
target: Hello, everyone.

source: My name is Justin Cooper, and I am a member of the Chicago Disability Pride Parade Committee.
target: My name is Justin Cooper. I am from the Disability Pride Parade in Chicago.

source: It is an honor to be a part of this wonderful virtual festival.
target: I am very glad to be part of the festival this year.

source: And I'm thankful for Disability Unite for giving me an opportunity to speak to you all.
target: I want to thank Disability Unite for letting me talk to you.

source: Now, normally during Disability Pride Month, we're showcasing our disability pride through various parades and events throughout the country.
target: Most years, during Disability Pride Month we have parades and events all over the United States to show how proud we are.

source: But due to the effects of COVID, we've all had to change our strategies on how we showcase our events.
target: This year, because of COVID, we have to do things differently.

source: Here in Chicago, we worked on a video with members of our committee, sharing our thoughts on what our disability pride parade and also the 30th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act means to them.
target: I made a video with the people I work with in Chicago. In the video, we talked about how important the Disability Pride Parade is for us. We also talked about the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).

source: During one of our meetings discussing the video process, we were joined by members of Disability Unite.
target: When we were making the video, we had a meeting with people from Disability Unite.

source: And we wound up talking about our plans for the parade and their plans for today's virtual festival.
target: We talked about the parade and this festival.

source: And the idea of collaborating together came up, and we talked about what that would mean to our respective disability communities.
target: We talked about working together and how much we can help each other.

source: To me, that meant working together with many disability organizations, not just in Chicago and New York, but throughout the country.
target: If we work together, we could help a lot of people all over the country, not just Chicago and New York.

source: We, not only as people with disabilities, but people with disabilities who take pride in being who they are, who take pride in showing solidarity with each other, and take pride in supporting one another during these times of a pandemic.
target: We are not just people with disabilities. We are people with disabilities who are proud of who we are. We are also proud to help each other, especially now when we have a pandemic, when so many people are sick with corona.

source: And hell, even before all of this, we've been the ones looking after each other, providing resources to make sure that we were able to live our lives and be a part of the community at large.
target: We have always helped each other, we made sure we can all live our lives and be part of our communities.

source: It's important for us to continue to love each other, fight for each other, and support each other during these times.
target: We have to keep loving each other. We have to fight for each other.

source: It's time for us to put together disability pride parades and disability festivals to work together and create awareness and making sure we continue to do this for years to come.
target: If all the people who plan disability parades and festivals work together, we can do more, and continue for a long time.

source: With that, I thank you for letting me have this time.
target: Thank you for listening to me.

source: I want to thank Matt and Elizabeth Axel for of reaching out to this Chicago Disability Pride Parade Committee and to Disability Unite.
target: Thank you Matt and Elizabeth Axel for inviting us to join you. Thank you Disability Unite.

source: On behalf of the committee, we look forward to working with you all in the near future.
target: We hope we will work together very soon.

source: And so with that, thank you so much for letting me do this.
target: Thank you all.

source: And I hope this is a very, very good festival today.
target: I hope this is a very, very good festival.

source: And let's all have a good time and celebrate disability pride.
target: I hope we all have a good time and celebrate disability pride.

source: Thank you.
target: Thank you.

source: Hey, guys.
target: Hey, guys.

source: It's Lachi.
target: I am Lachi.

source: And we're here to celebrate our community and how awesome each and every one of us are.
target: And we are here to celebrate our community. To celebrate how great we all are.

source: The disability community has true intersectionality.
target: People with disabilities belong to many different groups.

source: I mean, look at me. I'm a triple threat. And I don't just mean the acting and the singing and the writing.
target: Look at me for example. I am acting and singing and writing.

source: I'm black, blind, and I'm a b-eautiful woman.
target: But I am also black, and blind, and I am a b-eautiful woman.

source: We're diverse.
target: We are all different from each other.

source: We're creative. And we're full of love.
target: We are creative, and, we are full of love.

source: And we're grateful to have had regulation that has recognized us for 30 years. But here's to 30-times-30 years more.
target: And we are thankful for the ADA protecting our rights and hope that it will for many more years to come.

source: Hi, my name's Laura Benanti, and it's my absolute honor to introduce Evan Ruggiero to you.
target: Hi, my name is Laura Benanti. I am honored to introduce Evan Ruggiero (to you).

source: Evan is from my home state of New Jersey-- Jersey for life!
target: Evan is from New Jersey and so am I – I love Jersey!

source: He started tapping at age 5, and then as a sophomore at Montclair State University, he was diagnosed with a very rare form of cancer.
target: Evan started tap dancing when he was only 5 years old. When he was in the second year in college, he had cancer.

source: He had to undergo nine surgeries in six months and had to make the very difficult decision, ultimately, to amputate his leg.
target: He had nine surgeries in six months and had to make a very difficult decision. He decided to let the doctors cut off one of his legs.

source: 18 months after that surgery, and only two days after receiving his peg leg, he was tapping again.
target: A year and a half after the surgery, and only two days after he received a peg leg (a leg made of wood), he started tap dancing again.

source: He is one of the most courageous, inspirational people I will ever know.
target: I think Evan is a very brave and impressive person.

source: And it's just a wonderful thing that he is on this earth and that he is still able to perform for so many luminaries, including Ellen DeGeneres, the Bidens, on the Oscars.
target: It is just so wonderful that he is alive. It is great that he can still perform for so many important and famous people like Ellen DeGeneres, the Bidens, and even the Oscars.

source: That's incredible.
target: That is incredible!

source: He's a Drama Desk nominee. He was nominated for the Chita Rivera Dance Award.
target: He is nominated for many awards.

source: He's a really incredible person.
target: He's a really incredible person.

source: He's also very, very nice, and that goes a long way.
target: He's also very, very nice, and that is important.

source: Thanks for having me, and here he is.
target: Thanks for having me, and here he is.

source: Hey, I'm Thomas Ellenson, and I'm really pleased to have this opportunity to introduce Ryan Niemiller, who is both a really funny guy and is also a trailblazer for me and other disabled actors and comics.
target: Hi. My name is Thomas Ellenson. I am very happy to tell you about Ryan Niemiller. Ryan is a very funny person. A lot of actors with disabilities learned from him.

source: I followed his lead and wrote my own material, knowing that without doing so, people might not give me that first break and hire me otherwise.
target: He taught me that I should write my own shows so people will want to give me a job.

source: But also, like Ryan, I do not consider myself to be a disabled actor or comedian.
target: Ryan does not think about himself as an actor with a disability. I do not either.

source: Disability is just one part of my life.
target: I have a lot of other things in my life.

source: It does not confine my humor. It is just one of the sources.
target: I don’t only make jokes about my disability, I make jokes about other things too.

source: Ryan's described in interviews how the power of laughter early on saved him.
target: Ryan says that laughing helped him when he was young.

source: Kids can be cruel when people don't look like you, or in my case, talk like me.
target: When kids made fun of him because of how he looks. I felt that too. I talk differently than other people. Kids were mean to me.

source: When bullies might make fun, using wit right away is a great tool.
target: When people are mean to you, telling a joke can make them stop.

source: Ryan's known as the Cripple Threat-- the Power of Humor.
target: Ryan is also called the Cripple Threat.

source: Ryan's described in interviews how the power of laughter unites people, and it brings joy to life, including my own.
target: Laughing makes people like each other. It makes people happy.

source: It gives me great pleasure to introduce the guy we know and love from America's Got Talent, the one and only Cripple Threat, Cripple Threat Ryan Niemiller.
target: A lot of people saw Ryan Niemiller on America’s Got Talent. Now he is here. The Cripple Threat.

source: Thanks, everyone.
target: Thank you everyone.

source: Hello, everyone.
target: Hello, everyone.

source: I'm Victor Calise, Commissioner the Mayor's Office for People With Disabilities.
target: I'm Victor Calise, I am Commissioner for People With Disabilities at the Mayor office here in new York.

source: Welcome, everyone, to the first ever Disability Unite Festival.
target: Welcome, everyone, to the first Disability Unite Festival.

source: We are so excited to present you with an amazing program of music, dance, art, discussion, gaming, and more.
target: We are so excited. We have an amazing program of music, dance, art, discussion, gaming, and more.

source: I'd like to start by thanking the members of New York City Mayor's Office for People With Disabilities and the Disability Community Consortium Project, Access For All, who have worked to make this event possible.
target: I would like to thank all the people that worked to make the festival happen. The people from New York City Mayor's Office for People With Disabilities, the Disability Community Consortium Project and Access For All.

source: Together, with our community partners around the country, we've organized an incredible celebration during a difficult time.
target: Together, with many other partners, we organized a great celebration. And we are doing it in a difficult time.

source: Our country is in a period of upheaval, of change, of challenge, and sadness.
target: This is a difficult time for our country. It is a time of change, a time of challenge, and sadness.

source: But I have personally seen our community rise up to overcome.
target: But I see people who are trying to make it better.

source: We are stronger together, we work together, and we succeed together.
target: When we work together we are stronger, we can succed.

source: This event marks the 30th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act, an historic piece of legislation passed exactly 30 years ago that put into writing what we all know-- all people are equal, and all people must have equal access to opportunity.
target: This festival is celebrating 30 years of the Americans with Disabilities Act (the ADA). This important law says what we all know. The ADA says all people are equal, and all people must have equal access and opportunities.

source: We also celebrate the 50th anniversary of Disabled in Action, DIA, a civil rights organization birthed in New York City.
target: We are also celebrating 50 years of the organization Disabled in Action, DIA. DIA is an organization for civil right that started here in New York City.

source: Today, we share gratitude to the leaders of DIA, who orchestrated protests, had sit-ins, even chained themselves to buses in order for us to have the disability accommodations that we have today.
target: Today, we thank the leaders of DIA. These leaders organized many types of protests. They did all that for us to have the accessibility that we have today..

source: We also recognize our nation's communities of color and LGBTQ community, because civil rights movements support each other, help each other, and make each other strong.
target: We also want to thank our friends in communities of color and LGBTQ community. We thank them because communities that fight for equal rights help each other.

source: The disability rights movement is stronger because these civil rights movements happened, and we owe a debt of gratitude and continue to support them.
target: These communities make the disability rights movement stronger. That is why we thank them and we support them.

source: Since the passage and signing of ADA, we have seen tremendous strides in disability rights across all facets of life.
target: Since the ADA became a law there are many changes. We are making a great progress in disability rights in many different areas of life.

source: We have much to celebrate this July, but we also know that advocacy efforts must continue.
target: We are celebrating now, but we know that there is still a lot of work to do.

source: The Disability Unite Festival is the time and place to celebrate our community, celebrate our individuality, celebrate the parts of ourselves that make us unique and amazing.
target: The Disability Unite Festival is the time and place to celebrate our community. We celebrate who we are, we celebrate how special and amazing we all are.

source: However, at the same time, this is a platform to further advance equity and inclusion for everyone.
target: But, at the same time, the festival is also a good opportunity to keep working to make sure we are all equal.

source: While we are in separate locations, distance does not define a community.
target: We are now in many different places, but we are still a community.

source: Community lives within each of us.
target: The community is in us.

source: It shows itself in the way that we speak, the way that we act, the way that we love, the way that we advocate for ourselves, our families, our friends, and our neighbors.
target: We can see we are part of the same community in the way that we speak, and act, and love. We show it in the way we talk for ourselves, for our families, for our friends, and for our neighbors.

source: As a community, we are stronger than we know.
target: As a community, we are even stronger than we think.

source: Together, we do make change happen, we have made tremendous progress in the fight for disability rights, and we will continue fighting until every person in this country is included and has the same access and opportunity as anyone else.
target: Together, we change things. We now have many more rights for people with disabilities. But we will continue to fight until every person in this country is included in the community. Every person has the same access and opportunity as anyone else.

source: Now, enjoy the festival, and I look forward to coming together in person next year.
target: Now, enjoy the festival, and next year I hope to see you all here in New York City.

source: Happy Disability Pride Month.
target: Happy Disability Pride Month.

source: Miranda Hoffner and I are delighted to welcome you to this part of the show.
target: Miranda Hoffner and I are so happy to welcome you to this part of the show.

source: We are going to be highlighting artists from a variety of genres at all different stages of their careers.
target: We are going to see many different artists doing many different things.

source: The ADA is a necessary foundation for all our work.
target: The American with Disabilities Act, (the ADA), is very important for the work we do.

source: It frames the idea that disabled people might want to make art.
target: The ADA says that disabled people might want to make art.

source: It guarantees the access necessary for us to do so.
target: It says we must have access to everything we need to do art.

source: That's why we see so many different artists and arts groups today.
target: That is why there are so many different artists and arts groups here today.

source: But the ADA isn't enough.
target: But, the ADA is not enough.

source: Disability artistry leads us away from thinking about access as a series of regulations, to imagining access as a series of practices.
target: Disability art helps us think about accessibility and imagine how accessibility really works.

source: This is our future, and it begins now.
target: This is our future, and our future begins now.

source: Hi, my name is Miranda Hoffner.
target: Hi, my name is Miranda Hoffner.

source: I'm the assistant director of accessibility at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
target: I am the assistant director of accessibility at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

source: I'm so delighted to share with you two pieces that we commissioned as part of our ADA in the Arts series.
target: I am so happy to share with you two shows that were made as part of a series called ADA in the Arts.

source: The first up is from Heidi Latsky Dance, a partner that we've worked with at Lincoln Center for many years.
target: The first show is from Heidi Latsky Dance Company. Heidi latzky has worked with us at the Lincoln Center for many years.

source: We so respect her work.
target: We think her work is great.

source: It is a piece called SOLO FLIGHT ADA 30.
target: The name of the first show we will see is SOLO FLIGHT ADA 30.

source: And it features 15 artists, disabled and nondisabled, who are sharing with us their experience in isolation.
target: There are 15 artists in this show, disabled and nondisabled, who share with us their experience in isolation.

source: Enjoy.
target: Enjoy.

source: This next piece is part of Lincoln Center's ADA in the Arts Video Series.
target: The next piece is part of the ADA in the Arts Video Series from Lincoln Center.

source: It is in collaboration with Queens Theater and features Queens Theater for All Initiative.
target: This piece was created together with Queens Theater as part of the Queens Theater for All project.

source: It is a virtual reading of "Death Bites," written by Makena Metz, and it is performed, written and directed by a team of disabled artists.
target: It is a virtual reading of "Death Bites," written by Makena Metz. It was performed, written and directed by a team of disabled artists.

source: We hope you enjoy it.
target: We hope you enjoy it.

source: Hi, I'm Rebecca Cokely, the director of the Disability Justice Initiative at the Center for American Progress.
target: Hi, I'm Rebecca Cokely. I am the director of the Disability Justice Initiative.

source: Jackson Santi is a poet and spoken word artist who's based in Chicago and is just beginning his career.
target: Jackson is a young poet from Chicago who performs with words..

source: But when you hear his poem, you will understand that he has a great future ahead of him.
target: When you hear his poem, you will understand why he will be famous.

source: I present to you Jackson Santi performing his original work, "Photosynthesis and Other Life Lessons".
target: Jackson Santi will perform "Photosynthesis and Other Life Lessons".

source: Hello, I'm Ricky McKinnie, speaking for the Blind Boys of Alabama, and we want to let you know that singing brings us close
target: Hello, I am Ricky McKinnie from the Blind Boys of Alabama band. We want to tell you that singing brings us close to each other.

source: Hello, everyone, and welcome to the first-ever Disability Unite Festival, the intersection of everything about us with us.
target: Hello, everyone. Welcome to the first Disability Unite Festival. The best example of everything about us with us.

source: The Disability Unite Festival began as a project of the Disability Community Consortium Project Access for All and the New York City Mayor's Office for People With Disabilities on the occasion of the 30th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act.
target: The Disability Unite Festival started as a project of the Disability Community Consortium Project Access for All and the New York Mayor's Office for People With Disabilities. It started to celebrate 30 years of the Americans with Disabilities Act

source: As a community consortium, Project Access for All is made up of many different people and many organizations that all came together to make this possible.
target: Project Access for All is made of many different people and many organizations. All these people and organizations came together to make this festival possible..

source: This is truly a festival for our community by our community.
target: This is a festival for our community and we are the ones who did it.

source: Of course, none of this could have happened without the leadership of New York City's Commissioner, Victor Calise, from whom you just heard.
target: Of course, we could not do it without the leadership of Victor Calise New York City's Commissioner.

source: The team he put together is so incredible.
target: He has a great team.

source: They are seeing New York City through the coronavirus pandemic, and with weekly phone calls hosted by Jonathan Novick, we've had outstanding communication.
target: They are helping everybody now with coronavius pandemic (when so many people are sick with coronavirus). We had a call with Jonathan Novick every week, we had good communication.

source: And we, as the disability community, found ourselves getting to know each other even better and working together as a community.
target: And so we, the disability community, are getting to know each other even better we are working together (as a community).

source: We are also able to see the national network of Mayor's Offices for People With Disabilities in action, with each city helping the other during these difficult times.
target: We can also see how Mayor's Offices for People With Disabilities all over the country are working together. Cities are helping each other in these difficult times.

source: This is the positive outcome of this crisis.
target: This is the good thing about this crisis.

source: We have seen rapid growth of community and partnership from disability groups from across the country and even around the world.
target: We see our community growing and we are working together with disability groups from many states and even from other countries.

source: Now, not only is this the 30th anniversary of the ADA, but also the 50th anniversary of Disabled in Action.
target: Now, it is 30 years for the ADA. It is also 50 years for Disabled in Action (DIA).

source: And we are very honored to have their president, Jean Ryan, here to do the virtual ribbon cutting and start off the first Disability Unite Festival.
target: It is a big honor to have the president of DIA, Jean Ryan, here with us today to open the festival, to start the first Disability Unite Festival.

source: Disabled in Action is a civil rights organization committed to ending discrimination against people with disabilities-- all disabilities. Known as DIA, it fights to eliminate the barriers that prevent us from enjoying full equality in American society.
target: Disabled in Action is a civil rights organization. DIA works very hard to make sure people with disabilities have equal rights. People with any kind of disability.

source: Jean, would you like to say a few words?
target: Jean, would you like to talk to us?

source: Thank you.
target: Thank you.

source: We have had 50 years of many meetings, of many emails, of lawsuits and sit-ins, and some of us arrested.
target: We 50 years we had many meetings, many emails, we had fight in court and on the street. Some of us even sat in jail.

source: You remarked, Matt, about Commissioner Calise's role in our community.
target: Matt, you talked about the role of Commissioner Calise in our community.

source: I would like to call attention to his appointment to the Metropolitan Transit Authority Board, otherwise known as the MTA.
target: I want to talk about him being on the Metropolitan Transit Authority Board, the MTA that make descisions about transportation.

source: Commissioner Calise has the experience and know-how and the community lobbied together to get this appointment to happen.
target: Commissioner Calise has the ability to do this very important job and we all support him.

source: From here in, it is important to always make sure that we have a seat the table, and we have to cultivate our leadership to have people as capable as Commissioner Calise to push forward for appointments.
target: From now on, it is important that we always have a seat the table that people listen to us. And we need to make sure we have good leaders. To make sure they get to important positions.

source: I am excited by Disability Unite.
target: I am excited about Disability Unite.

source: The ability for DIA to have the support of thousands of disabled people and non-disabled allies gives us power.
target: For DIA to have the support of thousands of disabled people and non-disabled (friends of disabled people) gives us power.

source: I couldn't agree more, Jean.
target: I agree with you Jean.

source: Together, we have the power to create the change we need.
target: Together, we have the power to make the change we need.

source: Now, without further ado, we hope everyone has a great time at the Disability Unite Festival, and that you will join us in creativity, fun, friendship, and taking action to make our communities a place of equality, access, and inclusion for all, including people with disabilities.
target: Now, we hope everyone has a great time at the Disability Unite Festival. We hope that you will join us in fun, friendship, and doing. Help make our communities a place that has access, and inclusion for all, including people with disabilities.

source: Hi, my name is Chelsie Hill.
target: Hi, my name is Chelsie Hill.

source: I'm the founder of the Rollettes Wheelchair Dance Team.
target: I started the Rollettes Wheelchair Dance Team.

source: Our team is made up of incredible women with all different disabilities, but they do not let their disability define them.
target: In our dance team, we have wonderful women. We have women with many different disabilities, but we are a lot more than that.

source: Our mission is to empower women with disabilities to live boundlessly and shift perspective through dance.
target: We help women with disabilities be strong and live a full life

source: You may have seen us on NowThis, Huffington Post, BuzzFeed, Today Show, Good Morning America, Instagram and the Ellen Show.
target: We performed in many places such as, Today show, and Good morning America.

source: For more information about us, please visit RollettesDance.com and follow us on all social media channels.
target: If you want to hear more about us you can go online to RolletesDance.com. You can also look on Facebook and Instagram.

source: We are excited to be a part of Disability Unite Virtual Festival.
target: We are very happy to be part of the festival.

source: Please welcome the Rollettes Dance Team.
target: Please welcome the Rollettes dance team:

source: Steph Aiello, Samantha Lopez, Conner Lundius, Edna Serrano, Maria Rabaino, and myself Chelsie Hill performing We Can Together.
target: Steph Aiello; Samanta Lopez; Conner Lundius; Edna Serrano, Maria Rabaino and me Chelsie Hill. After the song we will perform the dance "We can together”

source: We know that gender equality is not a female issue.
target: We all know that equal rights for women is important for everyone, not just for women.

source: It's a social and economic imperative.
target: Treating all people the same way is the right thing to do It is important for people and for businesses.

source: Similarly, including people with disabilities in employment is about more than just equality. It's good business sense and beneficial for a company's success.
target: This is true also for people with disabilities. People with disabilities should have access to jobs, it is the right thing to do, and it is also good for the company where they work.

source: Equality is coming, but we can't just wait more than 100 years to realize gender parity in the C-suite and more than 257 years to close the gender pay gap.
target: Equality for people with disabilities will come. But we don’t want to wait for so many years like women waited. Women waited many years to have good jobs and get paid the same as man.

source: Nor can we wait for equality, access, and inclusion for all as we push forward our message.
target: We don’t want to wait for all people to be treated equally and be included.

source: So will we push forward the message of equity for people with disabilities, communities of color, and LGBTQ communities.
target: We believe that all people deserve equal rights, including people with disabilities, people of color, and LGBTQ communities.

source: Collectively, we have impact.
target: If we all work together, we will be strong enough to make things change.

source: The Female Quotient helps organizations become a catalyst for change and achieve ROE, Return On Equality.
target: Our organization is called The Female Quotient. We help other organizations make changes that are good for them.

source: We are advancing equality in the workplace and in media through solutions for change, measurements for accountability, and helping companies become equality fit.
target: Our job is to make sure people have equal rights. We help organizations make changes, so that they can be sure they give equal rights to everyone.

source: We provide business leaders with research, tools, experiences to promote equality and publish The Modern Guide to Equality, a playbook for activating change.
target: We teach business leaders how to make these changes. We also published a book called The Modern Guide to Equality, about how to make changes work.

source: We look forward to collaborating with Disability Unite and the disability community in solidarity.
target: We are looking forward to working with Disability Unite and with the community of people with disabilities.
